title: Adrenegic Transmission
author: ayobami
description: fact checking on the pharmacology of catecholamines with a quick look into their biochemistry

questions.question: phenylalanine is the amino-acid taken up into the adrenegic neuron
tyrosine is the amino-acid taken up into the adrenegic neuron
tyrosine is decarboxylated to form DOPA
reaction A is the rate limiting step of catecholamine synthesis
reaction B is a catalyzed by dopamine decarboxylase
reaction B is a catalyzed by dopamine hydroxylase
reaction D is not a methylation reaction
reaction D is catalyzed by PNMT(Phenylethanolamine-N-methyl transferase)
reaction A is catalyzed by tyrosine hydroxylase
reserpine alkaloids induce catecholamine transport into the vesicles
vesicle-monoamine transporter(VMAT) is inhibited by reserpine
amoxapine, a tricyclic antidepressant is a drug that is capable of inhibiting the norepinephrine transporter(NET)
dopamine is transported into its vesicle through vesicle-monoamine transporter(VMAT)
norepinephrine's neurotransmitter action is terminated mainly via enzymatic degradation
norepinephrine transporter(NET)'s main action is reuptake of catecholamines
dopamine is transported into its vesicle through vesicle-associated transporter(VAT)
